fields.name: Akre
fields.description: Akre is known for its celebrations of Newroz (Kurdish New Year).

fields.name: Alqosh
fields.description: The locals of Alqosh are Chaldean Catholic Assyrians, and home to the nearby Rabban Hermizd Chaldean Monastery, tucked away into the mountainside.

fields.name: Amedi
fields.description: Amedi (or Amadiya) is an ancient town, built on a mesa in the broader Great Zab river valley.

fields.name: Baghdad
fields.description: Baghdad is the capital of Iraq, and the second-largest city in the Arab world, after Cairo. It is located on the Tigris near the ruins of the ancient Akkadian city of Babylon, and the Sassanid Persian capital of Ctesiphon.

fields.name: Basrah
fields.description: Basra is Iraq's main port, although it does not have deep water access, which is handled at the port of Umm Qasr. The city is one of the ports from which the fictional Sinbad the Sailor journeyed.

fields.name: Barzan
fields.description: Barzan is a village located on the eastern shores of the Great Zab, with beautiful scenery comparable to Horseshoe Bend in the USA.

fields.name: Choman
fields.description: Choman is a city located 160-km northeast of Erbil, and the gateway for those wishing to ski or hike Hallgord or Cheekha Dar mountains.

fields.name: Duhok
fields.description: Duhok is well-known for its impressive natural landscapes, and is a city of peace and diversity, home to diverse ethnic groups, including Iraqi Kurds, Assyrians, Yazidis, and Arabs.

fields.name: Dukan
fields.description: The Dukan Dam was built between 1954 and 1959 as a multi-purpose dam to provide water storage, irrigation and hydroelectricity.

fields.name: Erbil
fields.description: Erbil (also called Hawler, Arbil, or Irbil) is the capital and most populated city in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq. The population is estimated to be around 1.2 Million inhabitants.

fields.name: Halabja
fields.description: The Halabja Massacre, officially defined by the Supreme Iraqi Criminal Tribunal as a genocidal massacre against the Kurdish people in Iraq under Saddam Hussein, killing between 3,200-5,000 people, and injuring 7,000-10,000 more.

fields.name: Hīt
fields.description: Straddling the Euphrates River, the city of Hīt was originally a small walled town surrounded by a halt moat and built on two mounds on the site of the ancient city of Is.

fields.name: Karbala
fields.description: The city, best known as the location of the Battle of Karbala in 680 CE, or the shrines of Imam Husayn and Abbas, is considered a holy city for Shia Muslims, in the same way as Mecca, Medina and Jerusalem.

fields.name: Kirkuk
fields.description: Kirkuk is home to a diverse population of Turkmens, Arabs, and Kurds. Kirkuk sits on the ruins of the original Kirkuk Citadel, which sits near the Khasa River.

fields.name: Korre
fields.description: Korre is the site where the Peshmerga and Kurds fought back against Saddam Hussein's regime, stopping them in their tracks before capturing the north.

fields.name: Koya
fields.description: Koya, also called Koye or Koy Sanjaq, is a town east of Erbil, with the Chaldean Catholic church of Mar Yousif, constructed in 1923, and an ancient Caravansary.

fields.name: Lalish
fields.description: Lalish is a mountain valley and temple, the holiest temple of the Yazidis. It is the location of the tomb of the Sheikh Adi ibn Musafir, a central figure of the Yazidi faith.

fields.name: Mar Mattai
fields.description: Dayro d-Mor Mattai is home to a Syriac Orthodox Church monastery on Mount Alfaf, located 20 kilometers northwest of the city of Mosul, Iraq.

fields.name: Marshlands
fields.description: The Mesopotamian Marshes, also known as the Iraqi Marshes, are a wetland area primarily located on the floodplains of the Euphrates and Tigris rivers

fields.name: Mosul
fields.description: Mosul is a major city in northern Iraq, serving as the capital of Nineveh Governorate. The city is considered the second largest city in Iraq in terms of population and area after the capital Baghdad, with a population of over 3.7 million.

fields.name: Najaf
fields.description: Also known as Baniqia, or An-Najaf al-Ashraf, and is widely considered amongst the holiest cities of Shia Islam and one of its spiritual capitals, whilst also remaining the center of Shia political power in Iraq.

fields.name: Nasiriyah
fields.description: Nasiriyah is a major hub for transportation, inhabited predominantly by Shia muslims, and the center of a date-growing area. The Euphrates merges for the final time with Tigris about 10km from the city.

fields.name: Rawanduz
fields.description: Rawanduz is close to the borders with Iran and Turkey, and home to some of the most beautiful canyons and waterfalls in Kurdistan and Iraq.

fields.name: Sulaymaniyah
fields.description: Sulaymaniyah, also called Slemani, is a city in the east of the Kurdistan Region of Iraq, not far from the Iran-Iraq border. It is surrounded by the Azmar, Goizha, and Qaiwan Mountains in the northeast, Baranan Mountain in the south, and the Tasluja Hills in the west.

fields.name: Tikrit
fields.description: Tikrit is a city in Iraq, located 140 km northwest of Baghdad, and 220 km southeast of Mosul on the Tigris River.

fields.name: Ur
fields.description: Ur was an important Sumerian city-state in ancient Mesopotamia, and was once a coastal city near the mouth of the Euphrates on the Persian Gulf, the coastline has shifted, and the city is now well inland, on the south bank of the Euphrates.

fields.name: Uruk
fields.description: Also known as Warka(h), it played a leading role in the early urbanization of Sumer in the mid-4th millennium BC, and was the largest urban area in the world at the time.

fields.name: Zakho
fields.description: Zakho, also spelled Zaxo, is located a few kilometers from the Iraq-Turkey border. The population of the town rose from about 30,000 in 1950 to 350,000 to 1992, due to Kurds fleeing other areas of the country.
